message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve passing through the parotid gland is the Facial nerve (CN VII), and injury to this nerve can result in changes in hearing, among other symptoms. Loss of taste from the posterior 1/3 of the tongue is a consequence of Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) injury. Loss of general sensation in the anterior 2/3 of the tongue is a consequence of Lingual nerve injury, which is a branch of the Mandibular division of the Trigeminal nerve (CN V3). Paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle is a consequence of Abducens nerve (CN VI) injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that passes through the parotid gland is the facial nerve, which is responsible for transmission of taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, among other functions. Therefore, options A and B are incorrect. The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the abducens nerve, so option C is also incorrect. The nerve responsible for hearing is the vestibulocochlear nerve, which does not pass through the parotid gland. Therefore, the correct answer is D, changes in hearing, which can be caused by injury to the facial nerve in the parotid gland region due to its proximity to the inner ear.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that passes through the parotid gland is the facial nerve, which has five branches. One of these branches, the chorda tympani, is responsible for taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect. Option (C) is related to the abducens nerve, which is not associated with the parotid gland. The facial nerve also has a branch called the vestibular nerve, which is responsible for hearing. Therefore, option (D) is a possible consequence of an intracranial injury to the facial nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that passes through the parotid gland is the facial nerve, which has several branches. Loss of taste from posterior 1/3 of the tongue is associated with the glossopharyngeal nerve and loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3 of the tongue is associated with the lingual nerve, both of which do not pass through the parotid gland. Paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle is associated with the abducens nerve, which does not pass through the parotid gland. Changes in hearing are associated with the vestibulocochlear nerve, which passes near the facial nerve through the internal acoustic meatus and can be affected by the same intracranial injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cranial nerve that passes through the parotid gland is the facial nerve (CN VII). Injury to CN VII can lead to changes in hearing, as the nerve also provides sensory input to the inner ear. Loss of taste from posterior 1/3 of the tongue is associated with injury to glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). Loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3 of tongue is associated with injury to trigeminal nerve (CN V). Paralysis of lateral rectus muscle is associated with injury to abducens nerve (CN VI).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only injury to the facial nerve which passes through the parotid gland can result in changes in hearing. Loss of taste from the posterior 1/3 of the tongue is associated with glossopharyngeal nerve injury, loss of general sensation in the anterior 2/3 of the tongue is associated with lingual nerve injury, and paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle is associated with abducens nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that passes through the parotid gland is the facial nerve, which is responsible for innervating the muscles of facial expression and some glands in the head and neck region. Damage to this nerve can result in facial palsy or weakness, but it does not directly influence taste or general sensation of the tongue, or the lateral rectus muscle. However, the nerve also has a branch called the chorda tympani, which carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and passes through the middle ear. Consequently, injury to the facial nerve can lead to changes in taste, and also affect the hearing due to the proximity of the chorda tympani to the middle ear structures. Therefore, the correct answer is (D) changes in hearing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that passes through the parotid gland is the facial nerve. Damage to this nerve can cause changes in hearing, as it also innervates the stapedius muscle in the middle ear. Loss of taste from posterior 1/3 of tongue is caused by the glossopharyngeal nerve, loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3 of tongue is caused by the lingual nerve, and paralysis of lateral rectus muscle is caused by damage to the abducens nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that passes through the parotid gland is the facial nerve. Injury to this nerve can lead to changes in hearing due to its involvement in the innervation of the stapedius muscle, which plays a role in the conduction of sound. Loss of taste from the posterior 1/3 of the tongue is caused by injury to the glossopharyngeal nerve. Loss of general sensation in the anterior 2/3 of the tongue is caused by injury to the lingual nerve. Paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle is caused by injury to the abducens nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that passes through the parotid gland is the facial nerve, which is responsible for taste sensation from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue and paralysis of the facial muscles. Therefore, options A and C are incorrect. The nerve responsible for taste from the posterior 1/3 of the tongue is the glossopharyngeal nerve. Therefore, option B is also incorrect. The nerve responsible for hearing and balance is the vestibulocochlear nerve. While it does not pass through the parotid gland, it can be affected by an intracranial injury and result in changes in hearing. Therefore, option D is the correct answer.
